key_terms.term: Idiom: Not to put too fine a point on it
key_terms.definition: Used for saying something in a direct way, even if it is unpleasant.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: If 'the paper records donâ€™t _________', it means they are not present or available. 'Exist' means to have objective reality or being.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after 'donâ€™t'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The absence of records necessitates interviewing people.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Don't has' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: After 'do not' (don't), use the base form of the verb.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The phrase 'not to put too fine a _________ on it' is an idiom. 'Not to put too fine a point on it' means to speak plainly or bluntly.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed to complete the idiom.
passage_highlight_phrases: not to put too fine a
collocations: 'not to put too fine a point on it'

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Not to put too fine a put on it' is not the correct idiom.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Recognize common idioms. 'Not to put too fine a point on it' means to be direct, even if impolite.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: We need to interview people 'while we still have a ________'. This refers to having an opportunity to do so, likely before people are unavailable or memories fade. 'Chance' means an opportunity to do something.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'a'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: It implies a limited window of opportunity.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Have a paper' doesn't fit the context of an opportunity to interview.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Still have a chance' means an opportunity still exists.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: If records aren't kept, 'then the stories are _______ too'. This means the stories will disappear or be forgotten. 'Lost' means unable to be found; or no longer possessed.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective (past participle) is needed after 'are'.
passage_highlight_phrases: if the records arenâ€™t kept...then the stories are
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Without records, the historical accounts (stories) will not be preserved.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Stories are pending' (waiting to happen) doesn't fit the consequence of not keeping records.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The consequence of not keeping records is often that information or stories are 'lost'.

title: The Nature of Wind
rawPassage: The worldâ€™s atmosphere is forever on the move. Wind is air in motion. Sometimes air moves slowly, giving a ________ breeze. At other times it moves rapidly creating gales and hurricanes. Gentle or fierce, wind always starts in the same way. As the sun moves through the sky, it heats up some parts of the sea and land more than others. The air above theses _____ spots is warmed, becomes lighter than the surrounding air, and begins to rise. Elsewhere, cool air sinks, because itâ€™s heavier. Winds blow because- air squeezed out by sinking, cold air is sucked in under rising, warm air. Winds will blow wherever there is a ______ in air temperature and pressure, always flowing from high to low pressure. Some winds blow in one place, and have a local name â€” North Americaâ€™s chinook and Franceâ€™s mistral. Others are part of a huge circulation pattern that sends winds over the _____ globe.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Air moving slowly gives 'a ________ breeze'. This contrasts with rapidly moving air creating gales. 'Gentle' means mild in temperament or behavior; kind or tender; not harsh or severe.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'breeze'.
passage_highlight_phrases: Sometimes air moves slowly, giving a

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Heavy breeze' is not a standard meteorological term. 'Gentle' contrasts with 'gales and hurricanes'.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Gentle breeze' is a common collocation for light wind.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The sun 'heats up some parts...more than others. The air above theses _____ spots is warmed'. This indicates these spots are warmer. 'Hot' means having a high degree of heat or a high temperature.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'spots'.
passage_highlight_phrases: heats up some parts...The air above theses
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Heated spots are hot.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Fierce spots' doesn't relate to temperature being warmed.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The verb 'heats up' and 'is warmed' clearly point to 'hot' spots.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Winds blow 'wherever there is a ______ in air temperature and pressure'. This refers to a disparity or variation. 'Difference' means a point or way in which people or things are dissimilar.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'a'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'An expected in air temperature' is ungrammatical and nonsensical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Differences in temperature and pressure are the fundamental cause of wind.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Some winds are part of a 'huge circulation pattern that sends winds over the _____ globe'. This means the whole globe. 'Entire' means with no part left out; whole.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'globe'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'The workers globe' makes no sense.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Entire' is a synonym for 'whole' or 'complete'.

title: Genetic Basis of Antisocial Behavior
rawPassage: Evidence for a genetic basis of antisocial behavior stems from several different lines of research. First, behavioral genetic studies of twins and adoptees have demonstrated that _______ plays a role in antisocial behavior, including various forms of aggression and criminality, by finding greater concordance for such behavior in genetically __________ individuals, compared to non-relatives living in the same environment. Second, various correlates of antisocial behavior, including personality factors such as impulsivity, sensation seeking, risk-taking, and callous-unemotional traits, are known to be at least partly genetically ___________. Third, psychiatric outcomes related to antisocial behavior, including antisocial personality disorder, gambling, and substance use and abuse, have also been ___________ in genetically informative designs, and each of these has demonstrated significant genetic links.

common_error_patterns.name: Semantic Precision
common_error_patterns.explanation: Multiple words might seem grammatically correct, but only one perfectly fits the specific meaning required by the context. Avoid overly general words when a more precise option is available.
examples: Using 'big' instead of 'significant' in an academic context.

A group of words centered around a noun that functions as a noun in a sentence (e.g., 'the emergence of new knowledge').

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The passage discusses a 'genetic basis' and 'genetically related individuals'. This points to inherited traits. 'Heredity' is the passing on of physical or mental characteristics genetically from one generation to another.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed as the subject of 'plays a role'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is about genetic influences on behavior.

distractor_analysis.reason: While environment plays a role, the sentence is specifically about genetic studies demonstrating the role of inherited factors.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Genetic basis' and 'heredity' are closely related concepts in discussions of inherited traits.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Finding greater concordance 'in genetically __________ individuals, compared to non-relatives'. This means individuals who share genes. 'Related' means belonging to the same family, group, or type; connected.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'individuals'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While identical twins are genetically related, 'related' is a broader term that includes other genetic relationships studied (e.g., fraternal twins, adoptees to biological parents).

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Genetically related' is a standard term in behavioral genetics.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Personality factors 'are known to be at least partly genetically ___________'. This means genes have an effect on them. 'Influenced' means having an effect or impact on the actions, behavior, opinions, etc., of another or others.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle (adjective) is needed after 'genetically'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Genetically directed' implies a stronger, more deterministic control than 'influenced', which allows for partial genetic effect.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Genetically influenced' acknowledges that genes play a part without necessarily being the sole determinant.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Psychiatric outcomes 'have also been ___________ in genetically informative designs'. This means they have been studied or researched. 'Investigated' means to carry out research or study into (a subject or problem, typically one in a scientific or academic field).
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed to form the present perfect passive 'have also been ___________'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While conclusions might be inferred from investigations, the outcomes themselves are 'investigated' or studied within the designs.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In scientific contexts, 'investigated' or 'studied' are common verbs for describing research activities.

title: Defining Crime and Punishment
rawPassage: A crime is generally a _______ act that results in harm, physical or otherwise, toward one or more people, in a manner prohibited by law. The determination of which acts are to be considered criminal has varied historically and continues to do so among cultures and nations. When a crime is committed, a process of discovery, trial by judge or jury, _________, and punishment occurs. Just as what is considered criminal varies between jurisdictions, so does the punishment, but elements of __________ and deterrence are common.

common_error_patterns.name: Semantic Precision
common_error_patterns.explanation: Multiple words might seem grammatically correct, but only one perfectly fits the specific meaning required by the context. Avoid overly general words when a more precise option is available.
examples: Using 'big' instead of 'significant' in an academic context.

A formal declaration that someone is guilty of a criminal offense, made by the verdict of a jury or the decision of a judge in a court of law.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: A crime is 'generally a _______ act'. This implies an act done consciously and intentionally. 'Deliberate' means done consciously and intentionally.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'act'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Criminal acts are often characterized by intent.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Discreet act' (careful not to attract attention) might describe some crimes, but 'deliberate' (intentional) is more fundamental to the definition of many crimes.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Deliberate' is a key term in legal contexts referring to intent.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The process includes 'discovery, trial..., _________, and punishment'. This refers to a formal declaration of guilt. A 'conviction' is a formal declaration that someone is guilty.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed in the list of processes.
passage_highlight_phrases: process of discovery, trial by judge or jury,

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Convicts' is a plural noun (people found guilty) or a verb. 'Conviction' (the act of finding guilty) fits the list of processes.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In the legal process, a trial can lead to an acquittal or a 'conviction'.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Punishment has elements of '__________ and deterrence'. 'Restitution' (recompense for injury or loss) is a common element of justice, alongside deterrence.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed, parallel to 'deterrence'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While rehabilitation is also an aim of punishment, 'restitution' (making amends for loss/harm) is often paired with 'deterrence' as primary elements considered in legal philosophy.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Restitution', 'retribution', 'rehabilitation', and 'deterrence' are key concepts in the philosophy of punishment.

title: Burger King's Market Challenges
rawPassage: Drive down any highway and you'll see a proliferation of chain restaurantsâ€”most likely, if you travel long and far enough, you'll see McDonald's golden arches as well as signs for Burger King, Hardee's and Wendy's the "big four" of burgers. Despite its name, though Burger King has fallen short of _______the burger crown, unable to surpass market leader McDonald's No. 1 sales status. Always the bridesmaid and never the bride, Burger King remains No. 2. Worse yet, Burger King has experienced a six-year 22 percent decline in customer traffic, with its overall quality rating dropping while ratings for the other three ______________ have increased. The decline has been _________ to inconsistent product quality and poor customer service. Although the chain tends to throw advertising dollars at the problem, an understanding of Integrated Marketing Communication theory would suggest that internal management problems (nineteen CEOs in fifty years) need to be _________ before a unified, long-term strategy can be put in place. The ________ of ________ in brand image and messages, at all levels of communication, has become a basic tenet of IMC theory and practice. The person who takes the customer's order must communicate the same message as Burger King's famous tagline, "Have it your way," or the customer will just buzz up the highway to a chain restaurant that seems more consistent and, therefore, more _________.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Burger King has 'fallen short of _______the burger crown'. This means failing to achieve or obtain it. 'Claiming the crown' is an idiomatic way of saying becoming the leader or champion.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A gerund or present participle is needed after 'of'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'winning the crown' is possible, 'claiming the crown' often implies asserting one's right or achieving a recognized top position, fitting the market leader context.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Claiming the crown' is an idiom for achieving the top position.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Ratings for 'the other three ______________ have increased'. Burger King, McDonald's, Hardee's, and Wendy's are competitors in the burger market. 'Contenders' are people or groups competing to win something.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed to refer to the other three burger chains.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is market competition.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Participants' is too general. 'Contenders' specifically implies competition for leadership (the 'burger crown').

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Contenders' are those who are competing for a prize, title, or leading position.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The decline 'has been _________ to inconsistent product quality...'. This means the cause of the decline is considered to be these factors. 'Attributed to' means regarded as being caused by.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed to form the present perfect passive 'has been _________'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Has been contributed to' means these factors added to the decline, but 'attributed to' more directly states them as the perceived cause.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Attributed to' is used to assign a cause or origin to something.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Internal management problems 'need to be _________ before a unified...strategy can be put in place'. This means the problems need to be corrected or fixed. 'Rectified' means to put right; correct.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed after 'need to be' to form a passive infinitive.
passage_highlight_phrases: before a unified...strategy can be put in place

distractor_analysis.reason: While problems need to be recognized, 'rectified' (corrected) is the necessary action before a new strategy can work.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Rectify' means to correct something that is wrong.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The '________ of ________ in brand image...has become a basic tenet'. This refers to the significance or value of something. 'Importance' means the state or fact of being of great significance or value.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'The'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Significant' is an adjective. 'The significant of' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'The importance of X' is a common phrase highlighting the value of X.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The importance of '________ in brand image and messages'. A unified strategy implies uniformity and lack of contradiction. 'Consistency' means the quality of achieving a level of performance which does not vary greatly in quality over time.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'of'. This noun is what is important in brand image.

distractor_analysis.reason: While quality is important, 'consistency' specifically addresses the 'unified' nature of the strategy and messaging across all levels, which is the focus of IMC.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In marketing (IMC), 'consistency' of brand message is a fundamental principle.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: A chain restaurant that 'seems more consistent and, therefore, more _________'. Consistency often leads to dependability. 'Reliable' means consistently good in quality or performance; able to be trusted.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed after 'more', parallel to 'consistent'.
passage_highlight_phrases: seems more consistent and, therefore, more
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Consistency in service and product leads to a perception of dependability.

distractor_analysis.reason: While consistency can lead to being reputable, 'reliable' is a more direct consequence of consistency and fits the customer's expectation based on consistent messaging and experience.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Consistency often builds trust and a perception of reliability.

title: Evolutionary Psychology and Human Behavior
rawPassage: In a sequence of bestsellers, including The Language Instinct and How the Mind Works, Pinker has argued that swathes of our mental, social and emotional lives may have _______ as evolutionary adaptations, well suited to the lives our ancestors eked out on the Pleistocene savannah. Sometimes it seems as if nothing is _________ from being explained this way. Road rage, adultery, marriage, altruism, our tendency to reward senior executives with corner offices on the top floor, and the small number of women who become mechanical engineers â€“ all may have their _____ in natural selection, pinker claims. The controversial implications are obvious: that men and women might _____ in their inborn abilities at performing certain tasks, for example, or that parenting may have _____ influence on personality.

common_error_patterns.name: Semantic Precision
common_error_patterns.explanation: Multiple words might seem grammatically correct, but only one perfectly fits the specific meaning required by the context. Avoid overly general words when a more precise option is available.
examples: Using 'big' instead of 'significant' in an academic context.

common_error_patterns.name: Incorrect Part of Speech
common_error_patterns.explanation: The sentence structure dictates the required part of speech (noun, verb, adjective, etc.). Choosing a word with the wrong part of speech makes the sentence grammatically incorrect.
examples: Using 'beauty' (noun) instead of 'beautiful' (adjective).

common_error_patterns.name: Opposite Meaning
common_error_patterns.explanation: This error occurs when selecting a word that means the opposite of what the context logically requires. Look for clues indicating positive or negative direction.
examples: Choosing 'decrease' when the context implies 'increase'.

common_error_patterns.name: Contradictory Context
common_error_patterns.explanation: The chosen word directly contradicts information stated or strongly implied elsewhere in the sentence or passage.
examples: Saying an animal is 'active at night' then choosing 'diurnal' to describe it.

common_error_patterns.name: Plausible but Weaker Fit
common_error_patterns.explanation: The selected word might be grammatically correct and make some sense, but another option fits the context more precisely, strongly, or idiomatically.
examples: Choosing 'good' when 'excellent' or 'optimal' is a better fit.

key_terms.definition: Connects the subject to a word or phrase that describes or renames it (e.g., is, seem, become).
Words that frequently occur together, forming natural-sounding pairs (e.g., 'strong coffee', 'make an effort').

Using the same grammatical structure for two or more related ideas for balance and clarity (e.g., 'to impart knowledge... to cultivate thinking... and foster innovation').
A group of words centered around a noun that functions as a noun in a sentence (e.g., 'the emergence of new knowledge').

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Our mental, social and emotional lives 'may have _______ as evolutionary adaptations'. This means they started or developed from these adaptations. 'Originated' means to have a specified beginning.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed after 'may have' to form the perfect modal.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Physical' is an adjective and doesn't fit the verb slot.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Originated as' or 'originated from' indicates the starting point or source of something.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: 'Nothing is _________ from being explained this way'. This means nothing is exempt or protected from this type of explanation. 'Immune from' means protected or exempt from.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed after 'is'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Nothing is implied from being explained' doesn't make sense in this context of broad applicability.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Immune from X' means not affected or exempt from X.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: All these behaviors 'may have their _____ in natural selection'. This refers to their origin or fundamental cause. 'Roots' metaphorically means the basic cause, source, or origin of something.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed after 'their'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While some behaviors are instincts, 'roots in natural selection' refers to the evolutionary origin of these traits, which may include instincts but is broader.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The idiom 'have its/their roots in' means to originate from or be caused by.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Men and women 'might _____ in their inborn abilities'. This suggests they might be different. 'Differ' means to be unlike or dissimilar.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after 'might'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Might explained' is ungrammatical. 'Might be explained' would be passive.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Differ in X' means to be different with respect to X.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Parenting 'may have _____ influence on personality'. This suggests a small or insignificant amount of influence, one of the controversial implications. 'Little' (with uncountable 'influence') means small in amount.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective or determiner is needed to describe 'influence'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is 'controversial implications' of evolutionary psychology, suggesting innate factors are more dominant.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Improved influence' doesn't fit the controversial nature or the likely argument from an evolutionary perspective which might downplay nurture over nature.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Little' before an uncountable noun indicates a small quantity, often with a negative or dismissive connotation (i.e., not much).

title: Copyright Law and Artistic Royalties
rawPassage: No one in Parliament would know better than Peter Garrett what largesse copyright can ______ so it may seem right that he should announce a royalty for artists, amounting to 5 per cent of all sales after the original one, which can go on giving to their families for as much as 150 years. But that ignores the truth that copyright law is a _______, recently exacerbated by the Free Trade Agreement with the US which required extension of copyright to 70 years after death. Is it scandalous that really valuable copyrights end up in the ownership of corporations (although Agatha Christieâ€™s no-doubt worthy great-grandchildren are still ______ the benefits of West End success for her who dunnits and members of the Garrick Club enjoy the continuing fruits of A.A. Milneâ€™s Christopher Robin books)? No. The scandal is that been peasants politicians have attempted to appear cultured by creating private assets which depend on an act of Parliament for their existence and by giving away much more in value than any public benefit could _______. In doing so they have betrayed.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: What largesse (generosity, money given) copyright can '______'. This means what benefits or advantages it can grant or bestow. 'Confer' means to grant or bestow (a title, degree, benefit, or right).
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A base form verb is needed after the modal 'can'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Royalty' is a noun (payment). 'Copyright can royalty' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Confer' is often used in formal contexts to mean to give or grant something, like a benefit or right.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Copyright law 'is a _______'. The passage then discusses controversial aspects like extension to 70 years after death and benefits to corporations, implying it's a matter of public outrage or disgrace. A 'scandal' is an action or event regarded as morally or legally wrong and causing general public outrage.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'is a'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The tone is critical, suggesting copyright law is problematic.

distractor_analysis.reason: While some might find aspects insulting, 'scandal' better captures the broader public/moral issue implied by the following criticisms.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: A 'scandal' often involves actions perceived as wrong that cause public outcry.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Agatha Christieâ€™s great-grandchildren 'are still ______ the benefits'. This means they are still receiving or getting good things from her work. 'Reaping the benefits' is an idiom.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present participle is needed after 'are still' to form the present continuous tense.
passage_highlight_phrases: the benefits of West End success

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'gaining the benefits' is possible, 'reaping the benefits' is a stronger and more common idiom for receiving positive results from something.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Reap the benefits' or 'reap the rewards' are idioms meaning to get the good results of one's (or someone else's) actions.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Politicians give away more value 'than any public benefit could _______'. This means more than could be shown to be right or reasonable. 'Justify' means to show or prove to be right or reasonable.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after the modal 'could'.
passage_highlight_phrases: more in value than any public benefit could
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The argument is that the private gain outweighs any reasonable public good.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Public benefit could satisfy' doesn't fit the comparison of value given away versus the value of public benefit.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Justify' often relates to providing a good reason for an action or outcome, especially when its value is questioned.

title: Astronauts' Work in Space

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: They need to make sure the '_______ Travel'. The context is astronaut work. 'Space Travel' is a compound noun referring to travel beyond Earth's atmosphere.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed to form a compound noun with 'Travel'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Inhale Travel' doesn't make sense.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Space Travel' is a standard term for journeys beyond Earth.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Make sure the Space Travel '_________ the craft'. This refers to travel external to the spacecraft, i.e., spacewalks. 'Outside' indicates a position not within.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb or preposition indicating location relative to 'the craft' is needed.
passage_highlight_phrases: the craft, they can see how seeds react
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The passage distinguishes between work inside and outside the craft.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Travel investigate the craft' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The passage contrasts 'inside' work with activities that would happen 'outside' the spacecraft.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: When '_______ the craft, they can set up experiments'. This again refers to being external to the spacecraft for activities like experiments. 'Outside' means not in a particular building or vehicle.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb or preposition is needed to indicate location relative to 'the craft'.
passage_highlight_phrases: the craft, they can set up experiments
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is work done external to the main vehicle.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'When on the craft' usually means inside or attached to the surface, but the contrast with 'inside' work suggests 'outside' for spacewalk-type activities.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The contrast between 'inside' and 'outside' activities is key here.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: They can 'clean ________ the space rubbish'. The phrasal verb 'clean up' means to make a place tidy by removing dirt and rubbish.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A particle is needed to complete the phrasal verb 'clean _______'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Clean express the space rubbish' is nonsensical.

title: Egg-Eating Snakes

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Snakes eat eggs 'as part of their ______': This refers to their regular food intake. 'Diet' is the kinds of food that a person, animal, or community habitually eats.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'their'.
passage_highlight_phrases: eat only eggs as part of their

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Eat' is a verb. 'Part of their eat' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: An animal's 'diet' refers to what it typically eats.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Some eat small eggs 'which are ______ to eat'. Small eggs would presumably be less difficult to consume. 'Easy' means achieved without great effort; not difficult.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed after 'are' and before 'to eat'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Small size implies ease of eating.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Are swallow to eat' is ungrammatical. 'Easy to swallow' would be correct, but the blank needs an adjective.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The structure 'are ADJECTIVE to VERB' is common (e.g., 'easy to see', 'hard to find').

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: They 'have to swallow ________, as the snake has no teeth'. This implies they swallow the eggs completely, without breaking them first. 'Whole' means entire; complete.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective or adverb is needed to describe how they swallow. 'Swallow whole' is an idiomatic expression.
passage_highlight_phrases: , as the snake has no teeth

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Swallow part' contradicts swallowing completely because of no teeth.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Swallow whole' is an idiom meaning to swallow something without chewing or breaking it.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: These snakes 'have _______ that stick out from the backbone'. The next sentence says 'The spines crack the egg'. This clearly identifies the word needed.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed as the object of 'have'.
passage_highlight_phrases: that stick out from the backbone. The spines crack...
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The word is defined by its function in the next sentence.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Have money that stick out from the backbone' is nonsensical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Look for direct references or definitions of a blank word in subsequent sentences.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The spines 'crack the egg _________ as it passes through the throat'. This describes the action of breaking the eggshell. 'Crack open' is a common phrasal verb/collocation.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb or adjective particle is needed with 'crack'.
passage_highlight_phrases: as it passes through the throat

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Crack the egg new' is not idiomatic.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Crack open' means to break something so that the inside is revealed or accessible.

title: The Haussmannization of Paris
rawPassage: Paris is very oldâ€” there has been a settlement there for at least 6000 years and its shape has been determined in part by the River Seine, and in party by the edicts of France's rulers. But the great boulevards we admire today are relatively new, and were constructed to prevent any more barricades ___________ by the rebellious population; that work was carried out in the middle 19th century. analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Boulevards were constructed 'to prevent any more barricades ___________ by the rebellious population'. This means to stop barricades from being made. 'Being created' is the present participle passive form, indicating barricades as the recipient of the action of creation.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A passive participial phrase is needed after 'barricades'. 'Barricades being created' (by the population).
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The population creates barricades; the boulevards prevent this.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Barricades creating by the population' is ungrammatical. Passive voice is needed.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The houses 'were _________ razed'. This emphasizes the totality or directness of the destruction. 'Simply' can mean merely or just, but also completely or absolutely in some contexts, fitting the idea of houses being completely demolished.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb is needed to modify the verb 'razed'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The razing of houses caused great distress.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Justly razed' (demolished fairly) contradicts the 'great distress' caused.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Simply' can act as an intensifier or to mean 'just' or 'merely'. Here it emphasizes the straightforward act of razing.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: When buildings 'are torn _________'. The phrasal verb 'tear down' means to demolish.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A particle is needed to complete the phrasal verb 'torn _______'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'torn apart' means to rip into pieces, 'torn down' is specific to demolishing structures.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Recognize common phrasal verbs. 'Tear down' means to demolish.

A structure that consists of anywhere from hundreds to thousands of galaxies that are bound together by gravity.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The universe is made of 'a mysterious, invisible ________ called dark matter'. Dark matter is a hypothetical form of matter. 'Substance' means a particular kind of matter with uniform properties.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'invisible'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Dark matter is described as a type of physical constituent.

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'material' is similar, 'substance' is often used in scientific contexts for a specific type of matter with defined (even if unknown) properties.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Substance' can refer to a type of physical matter.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Dark energy is 'a force that _________ gravity'. Dark energy is known to counteract gravity and cause the expansion of the universe to accelerate. 'Repels' means to drive or force (an attack or attacker) back or away; or to be repulsive or distasteful to.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present tense verb (3rd person singular) is needed to agree with the singular subject 'force'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Dark energy has an opposing effect to gravity on a cosmic scale.

distractor_analysis.reason: While it does oppose gravity, 'repels' is a more concise and scientific-sounding verb for a force that pushes away. 'Fights against' is more anthropomorphic.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In cosmology, dark energy is understood as a force that counteracts or 'repels' the attractive force of gravity, leading to accelerated expansion.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Scientists 'have not yet __________ dark matter directly'. This means they haven't seen or detected it. 'Observed' means to notice or perceive (something) and register it as being significant.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed after 'have not yet' to form the present perfect tense.

distractor_analysis.reason: One cannot 'smell' dark matter; the context is about scientific detection.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In science, 'observe' often means to detect or measure, not just see with eyes.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Confident it exists 'because of the __________ effects it appears to have on galaxies'. Dark matter's existence is inferred from its influence on gravity. 'Gravitational' means relating to or resulting from gravity.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'effects'.
passage_highlight_phrases: effects it appears to have on galaxies

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Gravity effects' is possible as a compound noun, but 'gravitational effects' (adjective + noun) is more standard and precise.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Gravitational' is the adjectival form of 'gravity'.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Effects on 'galaxies and galaxy _________'. Large groupings of galaxies are called 'galaxy clusters'.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed, parallel to 'galaxies'.
passage_highlight_phrases: effects it appears to have on galaxies and galaxy

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Flocks' refers to groups of birds or sheep, not galaxies.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Galaxy clusters' is a specific term in astronomy for large gravitationally bound groups of galaxies.

title: Causes of Truancy and Non-Attendance
rawPassage: In reality, however, the causes of truancy and ____________ are diverse and multi-faceted. There are as many causes of non-attendance as there are non-attenders. Each child has his/her own _________ story, and whilst there may often be certain identifiable factors in common, each non-attending child demands and ________ an individual response, tailored to meet his/her individual needs. This applies ________ to the 14-year-old who fails to attend school because a parent is terminally ill, the overweight 11-year-old who fails to attend because he is __________ about changing for PE in front of peers, the 15-year-old who is â€˜boredâ€™ by lessons, and to the seven-year-old who is teased in the playground because she does not wear the latest designer label clothes.

common_error_patterns.name: Semantic Precision
common_error_patterns.explanation: Multiple words might seem grammatically correct, but only one perfectly fits the specific meaning required by the context. Avoid overly general words when a more precise option is available.
examples: Using 'big' instead of 'significant' in an academic context.

common_error_patterns.name: Incorrect Part of Speech
common_error_patterns.explanation: The sentence structure dictates the required part of speech (noun, verb, adjective, etc.). Choosing a word with the wrong part of speech makes the sentence grammatically incorrect.
examples: Using 'beauty' (noun) instead of 'beautiful' (adjective).

common_error_patterns.name: Opposite Meaning
common_error_patterns.explanation: This error occurs when selecting a word that means the opposite of what the context logically requires. Look for clues indicating positive or negative direction.
examples: Choosing 'decrease' when the context implies 'increase'.

common_error_patterns.name: Contradictory Context
common_error_patterns.explanation: The chosen word directly contradicts information stated or strongly implied elsewhere in the sentence or passage.
examples: Saying an animal is 'active at night' then choosing 'diurnal' to describe it.

common_error_patterns.name: Plausible but Weaker Fit
common_error_patterns.explanation: The selected word might be grammatically correct and make some sense, but another option fits the context more precisely, strongly, or idiomatically.
examples: Choosing 'good' when 'excellent' or 'optimal' is a better fit.

key_terms.definition: Connects the subject to a word or phrase that describes or renames it (e.g., is, seem, become).
Words that frequently occur together, forming natural-sounding pairs (e.g., 'strong coffee', 'make an effort').
The basic form of a verb, usually preceded by 'to' (e.g., 'to go', 'to cultivate'). Often expresses purpose.
Using the same grammatical structure for two or more related ideas for balance and clarity (e.g., 'to impart knowledge... to cultivate thinking... and foster innovation').

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The sentence discusses 'causes of truancy and ____________'. Truancy is unauthorized absence from school. The next sentence mentions 'causes of non-attendance'. 'Non-attendance' is a direct synonym related to truancy.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed, parallel to 'truancy'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Truancy is a form of non-attendance.

distractor_analysis.reason: While truancy can be non-compliance, 'non-attendance' is a more direct and closely related term to 'truancy' and is used immediately after.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Look for repetition or closely related terms in the surrounding text. 'Non-attendance' is used in the next sentence.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: 'Each child has his/her own _________ story'. This emphasizes individuality. 'Unique' means being the only one of its kind; unlike anything else.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'story'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context stresses individual reasons for non-attendance.

distractor_analysis.reason: While a story might be novel (new/original), 'unique' better emphasizes that each child's situation is distinct and individual, even if the factors are common.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Unique' highlights the individuality or distinctiveness of something.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Each non-attending child 'demands and ________ an individual response'. This means they require or merit such a response. 'Deserves' means to do something or have or show qualities worthy of (reward or punishment).
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present tense verb (3rd person singular) is needed, parallel to 'demands', to agree with 'child'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Earns an individual response' is possible, but 'deserves' fits better with 'demands' to convey that the child is worthy of or merits this tailored approach.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Demands and deserves' is a common pairing emphasizing that something is both required and merited.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: 'This applies ________ to the 14-year-old...the overweight 11-year-old...'. This means it applies to all these different cases in the same way or to the same degree. 'Equally' means in the same manner or to the same extent.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb is needed to modify 'applies'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The principle of individual response applies to all examples given.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Applies commonly' doesn't fit the idea that the same principle applies to each distinct case. 'Equally' emphasizes the sameness of application across different cases.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Equally' is used to show that something applies in the same way to different people or situations.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The 11-year-old fails to attend 'because he is __________ about changing for PE in front of peers'. This describes feeling self-conscious or awkward. 'Embarrassed' means feeling awkward, ashamed, or self-conscious.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed after 'is'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While similar, 'ashamed' often implies guilt or wrongdoing, whereas 'embarrassed' is more about social awkwardness, which fits the PE context.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Embarrassed about' is a common collocation for feeling self-conscious due to a situation.

title: The Impact of a Three-Degree Temperature Rise
rawPassage: Three degrees does not sound like much, but it _______ a rise in temperature compared with the global heating that occurred between the last ice age, some 15,000 years ago, and the warmth of the eighteenth century. When Earth was cold, giant glaciers sometimes extended from the polar regions as far south as St Louis in the US and the Alps in Europe. Later this century when it is three degrees hotter glaciers everywhere will be melting in a climate of often __________ heat and drought, punctuated with storms and floods. The ________ for humanity could be truly horrific; if we fail to act swiftly, the full impact of the plants and animals with whom we share Earth. In a worst-case scenario, there might - in the twenty-second century - be only a remnant of humanity eking out a _________ existence in the polar regions and the few remaining oases left on a hot and arid Earth.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Three degrees '_______ a rise in temperature compared with...' This means it constitutes or stands for such a rise. 'Represents' means to amount to (a particular quantity).
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present tense verb (3rd person singular) is needed to agree with the singular subject 'it' (referring to 'three degrees').
passage_highlight_phrases: a rise in temperature compared with...
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The three-degree rise is being equated to or described as a certain amount of temperature increase.

distractor_analysis.reason: While it is a rise, 'proves a rise' is less idiomatic than 'represents a rise' when stating what a figure amounts to.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Represents' can mean to constitute or be equivalent to a certain amount or value.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Glaciers melting in 'a climate of often __________ heat and drought'. This describes extreme, difficult-to-endure conditions. 'Unbearable' means not able to be endured or tolerated.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'heat'. The option 'intense unbearable' is likely a typo in the provided options, with 'unbearable' being the intended single adjective. If 'intense' and 'unbearable' are separate, 'unbearable' is stronger given 'horrific' consequences.
passage_highlight_phrases: heat and drought, punctuated with storms
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context describes extreme and negative climatic conditions.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Tolerate' is a verb and doesn't fit grammatically as an adjective describing heat.
This seems to be two adjectives. 'Unbearable' alone fits. If 'intense' is chosen, it's a weaker fit than 'unbearable' given the dire context.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Look for overall tone. 'Horrific' consequences suggest 'unbearable' conditions.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The '________ for humanity could be truly horrific'. This refers to the results or effects of such climate change. 'Consequences' are results or effects of an action or condition.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed as the subject of 'could be'.
passage_highlight_phrases: for humanity could be truly horrific

distractor_analysis.reason: This is two nouns. 'Consequences' alone fits. The 'reasons' for the consequences are the heat and drought.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Consequences' refers to the outcomes or effects, often negative, of a situation.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: A remnant of humanity 'eking out a _________ existence'. 'Eking out an existence' implies a difficult, meagre survival. 'Diminished' means made smaller or less; or made to seem less important.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'existence'.

distractor_analysis.reason: A 'diverse existence' doesn't fit the negative, struggling context of 'eking out'.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Eking out an existence' is an idiom for surviving with difficulty. 'Diminished' fits this sense of reduced quality of life.

title: Ozone Damage to Trees: Urban Pollution's Rural Impact
rawPassage: Clones of an Eastern cottonwood (Populus deltoids) in the Bronx and other city spots grew to double the biomass of clones ______ outside small towns upstate or on Long Island, says Jillian Gregg, now of the Environmental Protection Agency's western ecology division in Corvallis, Ore. The growth gap comes from ozone damage, she and her New York colleagues report. Ozone chemists have known that concentrations may spike skyscraper high in city air, but during a full 24 hours, rural trees actually get a higher cumulative ozone exposure from urban pollution that _____ in and lingers. A series of new experiments now shows that this hang-around ozone is the ______ factor in tree growth, the researchers say in the July 10 Nature. "This study has profound importance in showing us most vividly that rural areas pay the _____ for urban pollution," says Stephen R Long of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. "This work should be a wake-up call," he adds.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Comparing city clones with 'clones ______ outside small towns'. This refers to clones that were put in the ground to grow. 'Planted' means to place (a seed, bulb, or plant) in the ground so that it can grow.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed to form a reduced relative clause modifying 'clones' (clones that were planted...).
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Trees or clones are put in the ground to grow.

distractor_analysis.reason: While clones are produced, 'planted' specifically refers to their placement for growth, which is relevant to comparing biomass in different locations.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In agricultural or botanical contexts, 'planted' refers to setting plants in the ground.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Rural trees get ozone exposure 'from urban pollution that _____ in and lingers'. This describes the movement of pollution by wind. 'Blows' means (of wind) to move creating an air current.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present tense verb (3rd person singular) is needed to agree with the singular subject 'urban pollution'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Breezes in' implies gentle movement, but 'blows in' is more general for wind carrying pollution.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Blows in' is often used for wind carrying things like weather, dust, or pollution into an area.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: This hang-around ozone 'is the ______ factor in tree growth'. The study shows its profound importance. 'Overwhelming' means very great in amount or effect; or giving too much of a thing.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adjective is needed to describe 'factor'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The ozone has a significant, dominant negative impact.

distractor_analysis.reason: While it might be surprising, 'overwhelming' better captures the dominant, decisive nature of the factor's impact as described by 'profound importance'.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Overwhelming factor' suggests a factor that is so powerful it dominates others.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Rural areas 'pay the _____ for urban pollution'. This means they suffer the negative consequences. 'Pay the price' is an idiom.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed as the object of 'pay'.

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'pay the cost' is similar, 'pay the price' is the more common and stronger idiom for suffering negative consequences.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Recognize the idiom 'pay the price', meaning to suffer the adverse results of an action.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Stress is connected to 'too many ______ to pay'. This refers to financial obligations. 'Bills' are demands for payment.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed after 'too many'.
passage_highlight_phrases: to pay and not enough time or money

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Too many money to pay' is ungrammatical for uncountable 'money'. 'Too much money to pay' could mean having to pay a large sum, but 'bills' are specific items one pays.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Pay bills' is a common collocation referring to financial obligations.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Stress 'is a common emotion that knows _____ borders'. The idiom 'knows no borders' means it is universal. However, if the intention is that it's not limited by many borders, 'few' in a negative sense (knows few borders = not limited by many) could fit, though 'no' would be more standard for the idiom. Given the options, 'few' is the closest to the idea of not being restricted by borders.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A determiner or adjective is needed before 'borders'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Stress is widespread and not confined by national boundaries.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Knows printed borders' doesn't make sense.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The idiom 'knows no borders' means something is universal. If 'no' is not an option, consider words that imply wide reach or lack of restriction.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Reported 'according to AP-Ipsos _____'. AP and Ipsos are known for conducting surveys or opinion polls. 'Polling' refers to the process of surveying public opinion.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed, or an adjective modifying an implied 'report' or 'survey'. 'Polling' can function as a noun here (the act of polling) or part of a compound like 'polling data/report'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'AP-Ipsos pants' is nonsensical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Organizations like AP (Associated Press) and Ipsos are well-known for news and market research, including 'polling'.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Germans feel stress 'more ______ than those in other countries'. This describes the degree or severity of stress. 'Intensely' means with extreme force or strength; to a high degree.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb is needed to modify 'feel stress more'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The comparison is about the degree of stress experienced.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Feel stress more early' is awkward and doesn't fit the comparison of intensity.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'More intensely' means to a greater degree or with more severity.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: People in the United States '______ financial pressures as the top worry'. This means they mentioned or referred to them as such. 'Cited' means to refer to (something) as evidence for or justification of an argument or statement, or as an example.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past tense verb is needed for the subject 'People'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Enjoyed financial pressures' is illogical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Cite X as Y' means to mention X as an example or reason for Y.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'At any point in time' emphasizes that something can occur or be true at any moment.

analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A verb phrase is needed to describe what 'debtors who' do.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is about overdue payments and poor collection practices.

distractor_analysis.reason: Debtors owe money; creditors are owed money. This is the opposite.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: A 'debtor' is someone who owes money. Their failure is often related to not paying on time.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Your first step is to talk to your debtor... '_________, , but Tim Vainio...believes...'. The 'but' indicates a contrast. 'This is OK' (referring to talking to the debtor) sets up the contrast with Vainio's more aggressive view on prioritizing recovery over relationship.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A short clause is needed, representing a common approach or understanding, before the contrasting view is introduced by 'but'.
passage_highlight_phrases: your first step is to talk to your debtor.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The initial advice to talk is a standard, acceptable first step, which Vainio then offers a counterpoint to in certain situations.

distractor_analysis.reason: Calling the act of talking to a debtor 'nervous' doesn't fit the context of it being a standard first step.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Look for contrasting conjunctions like 'but'. The clause before 'but' often presents a generally accepted idea that the following clause will challenge or modify.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Vainio believes 'that, ____________ _________ the focus should be on recovering as much money as possible'. This suggests that even in the initial phase (like the 'first step' of talking), the focus should be on recovery. 'Even at this early stage' fits.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverbial phrase is needed to specify when the focus should be on recovery.
passage_highlight_phrases: the focus should be on recovering
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: This emphasizes Vainio's view that recovery focus should start immediately.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'The last resort, the focus should be on recovering' implies recovery is only focused on at the end, contradicting Vainio's likely more proactive stance.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Consider the different perspectives. Vainio's view contrasts with a softer initial approach, suggesting immediate focus on recovery.

title: Language Learning Experience in Beijing
rawPassage: There were twenty-six freshmen __________ in English at Beijing Language Institute in the class of 1983. I was assigned to Group Two with another eleven boy and girls who had ________ big cities in China. I was told that language study required smallness so that we would each get more attention from the skillful teachers. The better the school, the smaller the class. I realized that my classmates were ready all _________ in English, simple sentences tossed out to each other in their red-faced introductions and carefree chatting. Their intonations were curving and dramatic and their pronunciation refined and accurate. But as I stretched to catch the drips and drops of their humming dialogue, I couldn't __________ it all, only that it was English. Those words now flying before me sounded a little familiar. I had read them and tried to speak them, but I had never heard them _________ back to me in such a speedy, fluent manner. My big plan of ______ the city folks were thawing before my eyes.

common_error_patterns.name: Semantic Precision
common_error_patterns.explanation: Multiple words might seem grammatically correct, but only one perfectly fits the specific meaning required by the context. Avoid overly general words when a more precise option is available.
examples: Using 'big' instead of 'significant' in an academic context.

common_error_patterns.name: Incorrect Part of Speech
common_error_patterns.explanation: The sentence structure dictates the required part of speech (noun, verb, adjective, etc.). Choosing a word with the wrong part of speech makes the sentence grammatically incorrect.
examples: Using 'beauty' (noun) instead of 'beautiful' (adjective).

common_error_patterns.name: Opposite Meaning
common_error_patterns.explanation: This error occurs when selecting a word that means the opposite of what the context logically requires. Look for clues indicating positive or negative direction.
examples: Choosing 'decrease' when the context implies 'increase'.

common_error_patterns.name: Contradictory Context
common_error_patterns.explanation: The chosen word directly contradicts information stated or strongly implied elsewhere in the sentence or passage.
examples: Saying an animal is 'active at night' then choosing 'diurnal' to describe it.

common_error_patterns.name: Plausible but Weaker Fit
common_error_patterns.explanation: The selected word might be grammatically correct and make some sense, but another option fits the context more precisely, strongly, or idiomatically.
examples: Choosing 'good' when 'excellent' or 'optimal' is a better fit.

key_terms.definition: Connects the subject to a word or phrase that describes or renames it (e.g., is, seem, become).
Words that frequently occur together, forming natural-sounding pairs (e.g., 'strong coffee', 'make an effort').
The basic form of a verb, usually preceded by 'to' (e.g., 'to go', 'to cultivate'). Often expresses purpose.
Using the same grammatical structure for two or more related ideas for balance and clarity (e.g., 'to impart knowledge... to cultivate thinking... and foster innovation').
A group of words centered around a noun that functions as a noun in a sentence (e.g., 'the emergence of new knowledge').
To originate in or be produced in (a particular place).

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Twenty-six freshmen '__________ in English'. This refers to their main subject of study. 'Majoring in' means specializing in a particular subject at college or university.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present participle is needed to describe what the freshmen were doing or their status.
passage_highlight_phrases: in English at Beijing Language Institute

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Getting in English' is too vague. 'Majoring in' is specific to academic study.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Majoring in a subject' is the standard term for a student's main field of study at university.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Boys and girls 'who had ________ big cities in China'. This refers to their place of origin. 'Come from' means to originate in.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle and preposition are needed to form the phrasal verb in the past perfect tense 'had ________'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Had come across big cities' means encountered them, not originated from them.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Come from' indicates origin or place of birth/residence.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Classmates were 'ready all _________ in English, simple sentences tossed out'. This describes their speaking ability. 'Talking in English' fits the context of conversation.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A present participle is needed to describe what they were doing.
passage_highlight_phrases: in English, simple sentences tossed out
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The context is about their English speaking proficiency.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Tying in English' makes no sense.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The description of 'sentences tossed out' and 'chatting' points to 'talking'.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: I 'couldn't __________ it all, only that it was English'. This means the speaker could not comprehend the full meaning. 'Understand' means to perceive the intended meaning of.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after the modal 'couldn't'.
passage_highlight_phrases: it all, only that it was English
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The speaker recognized the language but not the content.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Couldn't suspect it all' doesn't fit the context of comprehending speech.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Couldn't understand' is a common phrase for inability to comprehend.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: I had 'never heard them _________ back to me'. This refers to words being uttered or said. 'Spoken' is the past participle used in perfect tenses or passive voice.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past participle is needed after 'heard them' (object + participle construction, e.g., 'heard it said').
passage_highlight_phrases: back to me in such a speedy, fluent manner
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The experience was hearing words uttered fluently.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Heard them speak back' is possible, but 'heard them spoken back' emphasizes the words themselves being uttered back.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: The structure 'heard [object] [past participle]' is used to describe perceiving an action done to the object.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: My big plan 'of ______ the city folks were thawing'. This implies a plan to defeat or surpass them. 'Beating' means defeating in a game or contest.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A gerund is needed after the preposition 'of'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: The speaker's confidence or plan to outperform was diminishing.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Plan of relying the city folks' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: A 'plan of -ing' often describes the intended action.

title: Ancient Understanding of Celestial Bodies
rawPassage: In these distant times, the sun was seen to make its daily _______ across the sky. At night the moon appeared. Every new night the moon waxed or waned a little and, on a few nights, it did not appear at all. At night the great dome of the heavens was dotted with tiny specks of light. They ______ know as the stars. It was thought that every star in the heavens had its own purpose and that the _______ of the universe could be discovered by making a study of them. It was well known that there were wandering stars, they appeared in different nightly positions against their neighbors and they became known as planets. It took centuries, in fact, it took millennia, for man to _______ the true nature of these wandering stars and to evolve a model of the world to accommodate them and to predict their positions in the sky.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The sun 'make its daily _______ across the sky'. This refers to its apparent path or movement. 'Journey' means an act of traveling from one place to another.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'daily'.
passage_highlight_phrases: sun was seen to make its daily

distractor_analysis.reason: While 'flight' implies movement through air, 'journey' is more general for the sun's perceived path.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Journey' can describe a regular path or passage, like the sun's apparent daily movement.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Tiny specks of light 'They ______ know as the stars'. This describes how they were identified or named in the past. 'Became known as' is a standard phrase.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A past tense verb is needed. 'Became' + 'known as' forms a passive-like meaning (they were identified as).

distractor_analysis.reason: Simple past 'became' is sufficient for this historical description, as it's not necessarily showing a past action before another past action.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Became known as X' means that X became their recognized name or identity.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: It was thought 'that the _______ of the universe could be discovered'. This refers to hidden truths or mysteries. 'Secrets' are things that are not known or seen or not meant to be known or seen by others.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed as the object of 'discovered'.
passage_highlight_phrases: of the universe could be discovered
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Ancient peoples often sought to uncover the hidden workings or truths of the cosmos.

distractor_analysis.reason: While they might discover the system, 'secrets' better captures the idea of uncovering hidden knowledge, which was a common ancient pursuit.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Secrets of the universe' is a common phrase for the fundamental, often hidden, truths about the cosmos.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: It took millennia 'for man to _______ the true nature of these wandering stars'. This means to find out or establish exactly. 'Determine' means to ascertain or establish exactly, typically as a result of research or calculation.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after 'to' to form an infinitive.
passage_highlight_phrases: the true nature of these wandering stars

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Distinguish the true nature' (tell it apart) is possible, but 'determine' (ascertain/find out) better fits the long process of scientific discovery.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Determine' is often used in scientific contexts to mean ascertain or establish through investigation.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: In an 'attempt to _______ new students'. This means to attract or entice them. 'Lure' means to tempt (a person or an animal) to do something or to go somewhere, especially by offering some form of reward.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after 'attempt to' to form an infinitive.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Schools want to attract applicants.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The 'unofficial admissions ________ of four yearsâ€™ work experience'. This refers to a condition that was expected or required for admission. A 'prerequisite' is a thing that is required as a prior condition for something else to happen or exist.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'admissions'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Admissions leading of four years' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: A 'prerequisite' is a requirement that must be met before something else can be done.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Moved away from the old prerequisite 'and ________ have set their sights on recent college graduates'. This introduces an alternative focus. 'Instead' means as an alternative.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: An adverb is needed to show the shift in focus.
passage_highlight_phrases: moved away from the unofficial admissions...and
have set their sights on recent college graduates
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: It signals a change from the previous practice to a new one.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'And develop have set their sights' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Instead' is used to introduce something that is done as an alternative to something else.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Recent college graduates and 'so-called â€œearly career* ________'. This refers to people in the early stages of their working lives. 'Professionals' are people engaged or qualified in a profession.

passage_highlight_phrases: with only a couple years of work

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Early career lure' doesn't make sense for describing a category of people.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Early career professionals' is a common term for people who are relatively new to their field of work.

title: Central Pattern Generators and Animal Movement
rawPassage: In animals, movement is coordinated by a cluster of neurons in the spinal cord called the central pattern __________(CPG). This produces signals that drive muscles to _________ rhythmically in a way that produces running or walking, depending on the pattern of ___________. A simple signal from the brain instructs the CPG to switch between different ________, such as going from a standstill to walking.

key_terms.definition: Connects the subject to a word or phrase that describes or renames it (e.g., is, seem, become).

Neural circuits that can produce rhythmic motor patterns, such as walking or breathing, in the absence of rhythmic sensory or central input.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: A cluster of neurons 'called the central pattern __________(CPG)'. The abbreviation CPG stands for Central Pattern Generator. This CPG 'produces signals'.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed to complete the name 'central pattern _________'.

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Generates' is a verb. 'Central pattern generates' is ungrammatical as a name.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: Acronyms are often defined on their first use. CPG stands for Central Pattern Generator.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Signals 'drive muscles to _________ rhythmically'. Muscle movement for walking or running involves repeated tensing and relaxing. 'Contract' means to (cause a muscle to) become shorter and tighter in order to effect movement of part of the body.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: The base form of a verb is needed after 'drive muscles to' to form an infinitive.
passage_highlight_phrases: rhythmically in a way that produces running or walking

distractor_analysis.reason: While muscles also release, the primary action driven by signals for movement like running is contraction, followed by release, in a rhythmic pattern.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Muscles contract' is a fundamental concept in physiology of movement.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Running or walking depends on 'the pattern of ___________'. Rhythmic muscle contraction is driven by neural signals, often referred to as impulses or 'pulses'. 'Pulses' are single vibrations or short bursts of energy or sound.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed after 'pattern of'.
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Neural signals controlling rhythmic movement are often described as patterns of pulses.

distractor_analysis.reason: While the movement is rhythmic, it depends on the pattern of signals (pulses) that create that rhythm.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: In neuroscience, 'pulses' or 'impulses' refer to the electrical signals transmitted by neurons.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: The CPG switches 'between different ________, such as going from a standstill to walking'. These are different ways or forms of movement. 'Modes' are ways or manners in which something occurs or is experienced, expressed, or done.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A plural noun is needed after 'different'.
passage_highlight_phrases: , such as going from a standstill to walking

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Different moods' (emotional states) is irrelevant to switching forms of physical movement like walking.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Modes' can refer to different ways of operating or functioning, such as different gaits (modes of walking/running).

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Scientists 'make observations, have assumptions and do ________'. This lists key activities in the scientific method. An 'experiment' is a scientific procedure undertaken to make a discovery, test a hypothesis, or demonstrate a known fact.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed as the object of 'do'.
passage_highlight_phrases: make observations, have assumptions and do

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: 'After these have been done, they get their _________'. After conducting experiments and other scientific activities, scientists obtain outcomes or findings. 'Results' are consequences, effects, or outcomes of something.

passage_highlight_phrases: After these have been done, they get their

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: 'Then there is a lot of ________ from scientists'. Following results, scientists often share information or facts collected. 'Data' are facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
analysis_and_hints.grammatical_fit: A noun is needed after 'a lot of'. 'Data' can be treated as singular or plural; here, the context implies information.
passage_highlight_phrases: Then there is a lot of
analysis_and_hints.semantic_fit: Scientists share the information they've gathered.

distractor_analysis.reason: While scientists make discoveries, 'data' is the raw information that leads to discoveries and is shared.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'Data' refers to the information collected during research, which is then analyzed to produce results and discoveries.

analysis_and_hints.primary_reason: Scientists 'have a _____________ of world'. This refers to their understanding or conception of the world. 'Picture' can mean an impression of a situation or a person's conception of something.

passage_highlight_phrases: scientists around the world have a

distractor_analysis.reason: 'Scientific' is an adjective. 'Have a scientific of world' is ungrammatical.

analysis_and_hints.learning_tip: 'To have a picture of something' can mean to have an understanding or idea of it.
